data.text: If you had a pile of coins, how many do you think you could sort in 10 seconds?

Sort the coins for 10 seconds!
  
Time: 0 seconds
  
Coins sorted: 0

data.alt: A pile of pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters.

data.text:
You sorted 0 coins in 10 seconds.

How many do you think you could sort in 30 seconds?
Why do you think you could sort that many coins in 30 seconds?

data.alt: A pile of pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters.

data.text:
You predicted that you could sort 0 coins in 30 seconds.

You actually sorted 0.

Did you sort less, more, or the same number of coins as your prediction?
Why do you think your prediction was inaccurate?

data.alt: A pile of pennies, nickels, dimes and quarters.

data.text:
Imagine you were asked to sort coins for 10 minutes.

Do you think you would sort slower, faster, or at the same rate as you did for 30 seconds?

A local grocery store is looking to purchase a coin-sorting machine.

Click the Sort button to see how it works.

Time: 0 seconds

Coins sorted: 0

Here are your completed tables for the two machines.

Which one sorted more coins in 10 seconds?
Why did you choose that? What strategy did you use?

data.text:
How could you find the number of coins sorted when the time is only 1 second?

Describe your strategy and use it to complete each table.

data.alt: Student work and a thought bubble. The work shows a fraction, 15 over 120, equals 0.125. The numerator, 15, is labeled seconds. The denominator, 120, is labeled coins. The thought bubble reads, I think I need to divide the number of seconds by the number of coins sorted.

data.text:
Sally wants to find the unit rate for the relationship of the number of coins sorted to the number of seconds by dividing the number of seconds by the number of coins sorted.

Is that correct?
Why did you choose that? What strategy did you use?
Use the table to determine the unit rate for each machine.
What strategy did you use? Will it always work?

You have some information regarding coin-sorting machines, but some of it is missing.

Find the missing values and enter them into the table.
Describe how you found each type of value (number of coins, time, and unit rate)?

Noor and Eve are looking for a new coin-sorting machine. They see a machine that, in 4 seconds, sorts 10 coins.

Noor says the rate is 2.5 coins per second, and the unit rate is 2.5.

Eve thinks the rate is 0.4 coins per second, and the unit rate is 0.4.

Who is correct?
Why did you choose that? What strategy did you use?
You suspect that one of your coin sorting machines isn't working properly. Using the tables below, determine whether each machine is sorting the coins at a constant rate.

options.label: Both machines are sorting at a constant rate.
Machine E is not sorting at a constant rate.
Machine F is not sorting at a constant rate.
Neither machine is sorting at a constant rate.
